moves.1. d4: The QP opening, which has a reputation for slow, positional play.
moves.1... d5: Kaufman goes with a Classical response.
moves.2. Nf3: Alekhine loved to develop Knights early.
moves.2... c5: Kaufman chooses to play a Queen's Gambit with colors reversed, in response.
moves.4. Bxb8: The immediate QxP would give Alekhine 3 developed pieces to Kaufman's 0, but he chooses to postpone it.
moves.5... b6: The alternatives were ...P-QR3 or ...R-R1, neither of which appears significantly better than the text move.
moves.6. e4: Alekhine, with his advantage in development, wishes to open the board up further.
moves.6... dxe4: Kaufman captures the Pawn. 6...P-K3 may have been the safer alternative.
moves.7. Qxd8+: Alekhine goes in for the exchange of Queens.
moves.8. Ne5: Kaufman resigns. Alekhine threatens 9 N-B6 ch forking K and QR, and 9 NxP ch forking K and KR. 8...K-K1 is countered by 9 B-N5 ch forcing the King back to Q1 and allowing the "shakrukh". [Interposing with 9...B-Q2 doesn't help, as 10 BxB ch still forces the K back to Q1.] Well played by Alekhine.
